Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Interacting influences of climate, land use, and other disturbances on regime shifts in forest ecosystems: Holocene dynamics in the northeastern US
Award.AbstractNarration:
The manner in which climate change, human land-use and natural disturbances interact to disrupt natural systems remains a critical concern for science and society. With increasing rates of climate and land-use change the rate and magnitude of ecosystem changes will likely increase with major effects on critical services to humankind including the availability of natural resources and the ability of nature to buffer climate impacts. This research project will advance the understanding of how climate change interacts with human and natural disturbances to generate abrupt ecological changes by developing and analyzing a rich array of paleoecological, paleoclimatic, and archaeological data over the past 13,000 years. The study will focus on periods characterized by sharp declines in oak and hemlock due to rapid climate change, major droughts, insect outbreaks, changing human-population and land-use regimes (e.g., deforestation, fire) at ca. 6000, 5500, and 4000 yr BP and the time of European settlement. New methodologies will be applied to analyze ecosystem change and to explore the consequences for the earth?s future. The research will concentrate on southern New England and three important, contrasting landscapes: the coast (Cape Cod and islands), near-coastal wetland area (Taunton River), and the inland-riverine area of the Connecticut and Deerfield Rivers.

The collaborators will apply their strengths in ecological, biophysical and social science to advance: (i) interdisciplinary training at undergraduate, graduate, postdoctoral and mid-career levels; (ii) communication and engagement with broad audiences of scientists, decision makers, and policy makers; and (iii) environmental and conservation policy. These efforts will capitalize on existing institutional strengths: Harvard Forest Programs in Science and Policy Integration, Program on Conservation Innovation, Summer Research in Ecology (NSF REU), Bullard Fellowship Program, Archaeology/ Paleoecology Field School and LTER program; the new LTER Network collaboration with the MBL Logan Journalist Program; the Emerson College undergraduate program in Science Communication and graduate programs in Geology and Geophysics at the University of Wyoming and Anthropology and Archaeology at the University of Massachusetts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This archaeological research is a component of a larger collaborative project aimed at advancing broad understandings of New England ecosystem dynamics in the face of substantial global climate change since the end of the Pleistocene. Collaborating with researchers in the field of paleoenvironmental studies, the three primary research objectives were to: (1) evaluate Holocene ecosystem dynamics across time and space; (2) evaluate the drivers and triggers of ecosystem dynamics; and (3) test hypotheses about the role of humans and disturbance in ecological dynamics. The last objective has been the area of focus for our archaeological research.

Archaeological research for this project allowed us to: (1) explore the link between environmental change and cultural development in northeastern North America; (2) position our archaeological group to apply new ecological perspectives to our research; and (3) inform modern land management practice by our private and public conservation partners in the region. We tested three hypotheses within our study region, the state of Massachusetts, which focus broadly on the relationships between cultural change and environmental dynamics:

H0 - Progressive cultural development and influence over the environment.

HA - Cultural continuity, response to environmental change with minimal ecological impact.

HB - Context specific cultural adaptation in reaction to environmental and cultural conditions.

The archaeological investigation involved an intensive state-wide site evaluation and spatial analysis of recorded pre-contact sites at two levels: (1) across the state of Massachusetts, and (2) a more intensive analysis of three sub-regions in Massachusetts (Martha’s Vineyard, the Taunton River Basin, and the Deerfield River Valley). These focus areas represent three contrasting cultural landscapes: a habitat-rich island, a near-coastal lowland, and an interior upland.

Data from 2,018 pre-contact Native American sites across the state of Massachusetts were collected from site forms at the Massachusetts Historical Commission, with further details obtained from academic articles, reports from the Massachusetts Archaeological Society Bulletin, and reports from local cultural resource management firms. This data will be available to other scholars interested in the archaeology of southern New England through the Digital Archaeological Record (tDAR) and the Harvard Forest Data Archive.

The state-wide analysis revealed the dominance of short term occupations throughout the pre-contact period, with only a slight increase in seasonal and sedentary sites in the Late Woodland period (1000-450 BP). In terms of site distribution during the Archaic Period (9500-3000 BP), we see an overall trend from very low density and widespread distribution in the Early Archaic (9500-8000 BP) period towards regional congregations along river valleys, coastal, and near-coastal regions during the later periods. The state-wide analysis also revealed very frequent re-use of sites over more than one archaeological time period. Most sites in our study show evidence of being used in more than one time period. This observation resulted in substantial challenges in our subsequent sub-regional analysis, because it was not clear what cultural activities were occuring at what time due to the frequent re-use of most sites, irregular archaeological recording practices, and the lack of clear soil stratigraphy in Massachusetts.

For the sub-regional analysis, data was examined from sites with clear temporal affiliations (having either radiocarbon-dated material or diagnostic projectile points). This analysis used data from 15 sites in the Deerfield River Valley, 187 sites in the Taunton River Basin, and 22 sites on Martha’s Vineyard. Diagnostic projectile points in all three sub-regions attest to continuous habitation since at least the late Paleoindian Period (10,000-9000 BP) in all three subregions. Radiocarbon dated samples, however, point to differing patterns of settlement and land use in the sub-regions over time. On Martha’s Vineyard, available radiocarbon-dated samples suggest low-density settlement up until the Late Woodland (1000-450 BP) period, when there is a sharp incline in samples dated to this period from its onset. Radiocarbon-dated samples from the Deerfield River Valley show low population density throughout pre-contact history, with a slight peak in the Late Archaic (5000-3000 BP) period. Finally, samples from the Taunton River Basin suggest a slowly increasing site density throughout the Archaic Period, falling at the end of the Late Archaic, and again gradually increasing until it peaks for a second time in the Late Woodland period.

This study provided training and professional development opportunities to two post-doctoral research associates and one graduate research assistant. It has provided important training in data compilation, management, and analysis that is broadly applicable in archaeological and anthropological sciences. This project will also have real and lasting impacts to the disciplines of ecology and archaeology. By adding critical knowledge by testing the link between environmental change and cultural development in northeastern North America, our findings can inform modern land management practices in the region. We also anticipate that this research will impact the ways that archaeologists ask questions about and interpret the past.
